comment.author: 63191264@N00
comment._content: Henry Richmund Inigo-Jones Born 17th December 1891 London. The 1901 census records him living at the family home Kelston Park, Bath. www.imagesofengland.org.uk/Details/Default.aspx?id=399989 and en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kelston_Park with his mother Elinor Margaret [b.1860 London], older sisters Alise [b.1885 London] and Maud [b.1890 London] and eleven staff. His father [who is Major-General Richmund Inogo-Jones] is not recorded as living at the house. The 1911 census records him living at 17 Grosvenor Square, London with his grandmother Margaret Charteris [b.1835 Dublin, Ireland] along with, again, eleven domestic servants. He joined the Scots Guards as a 2nd Lieutenant in 1912 and was promoted Lieutenant in 1913. Died 14th September 1914 France. Left £2240 9s 5d to his mother Elinor Margaret Jones and Edmund Butler Charteris [half-brother?] His father predeceased him on 20th July 1914.

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content:
Lieutenant Henry Richmund Inigo Jones SCOTS GUARDS.  Son of Major General Inigo Richmund Jones CB CVO (Late SCOTS GUARDS) (23 Sep 1848-20 July 1914) and his second wife Elinor Margaret Charteris.  In 1901 his father would have been away commanding the Guards Brigade fighting in the Boer War.  Grandson of Lieutenant Colonel Inigo William Jones JP DL 1st Dragoons of Kelston Park, Somerset, (b 1806-d 1878).

Lieutenant H R I Jones SCOTS GUARDS was killed in action on 14th September 1914, aged 22.   On 14th August 1914 the 1st Battalion Scots Guards were part of 1st (Guards) Brigade in 1st Division of the BEF.//

comment.author: 68451334@N04
comment._content:
You have to feel sorry for his mother, losing her husband and son both within a couple of months.

To those of you researching and finding out the personal histories of these people

THANKYOU.

comment._content:
Commonwealth Wargraves Commission has following details
Name: INIGO-JONES, HENRY RICHARD 
Initials: H R 
Nationality: United Kingdom 
Rank: Lieutenant 
Regiment/Service: Scots Guards 
Unit Text: 1st Bn. 
Age: 22 
Date of Death: 14/09/1914 
Additional information: Son of Maj. Gen. Inigo-Jones, C.B.,C.V.O., and Mrs. Elinor M. Inigo-Jones, of 10, South Audley St., London, W. 
Casualty Type: Commonwealth War Dead 
Memorial: LA FERTE-SOUS-JOUARRE MEMORIAL

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content:
1st Battalion SCOTS GUARDS landed in France at Le Havre on 14th August 1914 as part of 1st (Guards) Brigade in 1st Division of the BEF (1st Coldsream Guards; 1st Scots Guards; 1st Black Watch; 1st Royal Munster Fusiliers).
 
Lieutenant Henry Inigo Jones is likely to have seen action at Mons 23-24 August; in the rearguard at Etreux 27 August; in the BEF counterattack on the Marne 7-10 September; and then in attacking the German line in the Battle of the Aisne, from 12 September 1914.

Colonel Ernest Swinton, the Official British War Correspondent recorded:  "On Monday, the 14th (September), those of our troops which had on the previous day crossed the Aisne, after driving in the German rear guards on that evening, found portions of the enemy's forces in prepared defensive positions on the right bank and could do little more than secure a footing north of the river.  This, however, they maintained in spite of two counter-attacks delivered at dusk and 10 p.m., in which the fighting was severe."

Lieutenant Henry Inigo Jones's father, Major General Inigo Richmund Jones, was twice married.  His first wife, Alice Charlotte Matilda (Dawson) of Rollesby Hall, Norfolk, m 1878, died 26 March 1885 aged 34, (probably of complications after childbirth), with whom he had three daughters; Gladys Agnes Margaret Inigo Jones, 4 May 1879 [died 16 June 1897]; Eva Adela Mabel Inigo Jones, 1 January 1883; Allix Doreen Inigo Jones, 22 February 1885.

With his second wife, Elinor Margaret (Charteris), m 12 July 1888, he had a daughter Maud Evelyn Inigo Jones, b 18 April 1889, (later Viscountess Cross) and Henry Richmund Inigo Jones, b 17 December 1891.  Their family home in 1914 appears to have been 10 South Audley Street, Westminster.//

comment.author: 63191264@N00
comment._content:
I was trying to figure out from the photograph, what was the armband that Henry appears to be wearing on his left arm. A bit of speculation here, bear with me...
If the Battalion arrived in France on 14th August 1914 and his father died only about four weeks before that, I wonder if he had the photo taken before he embarked for France but after his father’s death and the armband is a black, mourning, armband [which would be correct and permissible dress for an officer - but not for an enlisted man].
This gives a possible date range for the photograph being taken of sometime between 20th July – 14th August 1914.

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content:
Good spot 'Liits'! It is almost certainly a black mourning armband. He would in all likelihood have attended his father's funeral in uniform. Given his rank and distinguished service it would probably have been a Regimental funeral, or a family funeral at Kelston Park in Somerset and a Regimental memorial service.

It would be reasonable to further speculate that the photograph was taken during whatever pre-embarkation leave the Battalion officers might have been allowed. The date might be further narrowed to perhaps between the declaration of war on Tuesday 4th August and Lt Jones reporting back for duty at Chelsea Barracks when 1st Battalion Scots Guards mustered to entrain for Southampton, perhaps Monday 10th August. A military family would have had no illusions as to the gravity of events and this, as are most of the later portraits in the portfolio, is undoubtedly a 'keepsake' photograph for his mother to remember him by. Company Subalterns would have been very busy and he may only have had the briefest opportunity to say goodbye to his family.//
